page.title:
Background - MTBE Use
Background - MTBE Use
page.footer:
federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State
federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State
page.enlisting:
MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s Required seasonal use beginning 1992 – Winter oxygenated fuels program – Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions – Most refiners selected MTBE – Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996 – Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute to the formation of photochemical smog – Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates – California regulations permit discretionary use, but 3 MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s Required seasonal use beginning 1992 – Winter oxygenated fuels program – Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions – Most refiners selected MTBE – Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996 – Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute to the formation of photochemical smog
MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s
Required seasonal use beginning 1992
– Winter oxygenated fuels program
– Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions
– Most refiners selected MTBE
– Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume
Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996
– Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control
emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute
to the formation of photochemical smog
– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates
– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates
– California regulations permit discretionary use, but 3
– California regulations permit discretionary use, but
3
in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)
in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)

Gasoline demand and supply – Gasoline demand in California during 2003 estimated in range of 15.6 to 16 billion gallons – Demand expected to increase between 1.6 and 3 – Refineries located in California produce the – Imports of gasoline and blending components increase each year, while refinery capacity remains relatively flat (annual growth rate of 0.5 percent) – California represents nearly 12 percent of United Gasoline demand and supply – Gasoline demand in California during 2003

page.title:
Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE
page.enlisting:
Water resource contamination concerns – Detections of MTBE in water wells – Prediction that contamination would spread and cleanup costs dramatically increase Potential health concerns also raised Studies ordered by California Legislature to determine: – Cost to eliminate MTBE – Assess risk to people and the environment of – Initial work conducted by California Energy Commission and University of California Water resource contamination concerns – Detections of MTBE in water wells – Prediction that contamination would spread and
Water resource contamination concerns
– Detections of MTBE in water wells
– Prediction that contamination would spread and
cleanup costs dramatically increase Potential health concerns also raised Studies ordered by California Legislature to determine: – Cost to eliminate MTBE – Assess risk to people and the environment of
cleanup costs dramatically increase
Potential health concerns also raised
Studies ordered by California Legislature to
determine:
– Cost to eliminate MTBE
– Assess risk to people and the environment of
– Initial work conducted by California Energy Commission and University of California
– Initial work conducted by California Energy
Commission and University of California
continued use
continued use

page.title:
Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)
page.enlisting:
Initial studies completed by late 1998 – UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at $340 MM to $1.5 billion – CEC - Gasoline production cost would only increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol • Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450 Executive Order issued by Governor Davis during March 1999 – Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002 – California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute Initial studies completed by late 1998 – UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at
Initial studies completed by late 1998
– UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at
$340 MM to $1.5 billion
$340 MM to $1.5 billion
– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only
– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only
increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol • Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450
increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol
• Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450
Executive Order issued by Governor Davis during March 1999 – Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002 – California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute

during March 1999
– Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002
– California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends
gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol
only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute
million
million

page.title:
Subsequent Actions - 1999
Subsequent Actions - 1999
page.enlisting:
Energy Commission determines that timetable to remove MTBE cannot be advanced ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations – Ethanol only permissible oxygenate – Gasoline specifications changed • lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm • lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent • aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent • distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F. • olefins unchanged
Energy Commission determines that
timetable to remove MTBE cannot be
advanced
ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations
– Ethanol only permissible oxygenate
– Gasoline specifications changed
• lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm
• lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent
• aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent
• distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F.
• olefins unchanged

page.title:
Subsequent Actions - 2001
Subsequent Actions - 2001
page.enlisting:
US EPA denies request by California to receive waiver from the federal minimum oxygen requirement - June 12 – 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003 – Failure to issue waiver will cost California California Air Resources Board sues US EPA to obtain waiver - August 13 – Final arguments heard in Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision US EPA denies request by California to receive waiver from the federal minimum oxygen requirement - June 12 – 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an

receive waiver from the federal minimum
oxygen requirement - June 12
– 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an
oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003 – Failure to issue waiver will cost California

to obtain waiver - August 13

Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision

page.title:
Subsequent Actions - 2002
Subsequent Actions - 2002
page.enlisting:
CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout – 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon – $540 MM to $1 billion per year Stillwater Report raised supply and infrastructure concerns – Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline supply and increased potential for price spikes Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility – Several companies sued for MTBE contamination – Finding of “defective product” by jury – Settlement for $68 million CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout – 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon – $540 MM to $1 billion per year Stillwater Report raised supply and infrastructure concerns – Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline supply and increased potential for price spikes
CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout
– 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon
– $540 MM to $1 billion per year
Stillwater Report raised supply and
infrastructure concerns
– Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline
supply and increased potential for price spikes
Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility – Several companies sued for MTBE contamination – Finding of “defective product” by jury – Settlement for $68 million
Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility
– Several companies sued for MTBE contamination
– Finding of “defective product” by jury
– Settlement for $68 million

page.title:
Subsequent Actions - 2002 (cont.)
Subsequent Actions - 2002 (cont.)
page.enlisting:
Governor Davis issues Exec. Order D-52-02 – MTBE phaseout delayed until January 1, 2004 A number of refining companies announce early phaseout of MTBE in California – BP, ChevronTexaco, ExxonMobil, and Shell plan to – The refineries operated by these companies required less modifications & more self-sufficient with regard to their distribution infrastructure – Including Phillips, 60-70 percent of California’s Governor Davis issues Exec. Order D-52-02 – MTBE phaseout delayed until January 1, 2004 A number of refining companies announce early phaseout of MTBE in California – BP, ChevronTexaco, ExxonMobil, and Shell plan to

– MTBE phaseout delayed until January 1, 2004

page.title:
Elements Necessary for a Successful MTBE Phaseout
Elements Necessary for a Successful
MTBE Phaseout
page.enlisting:
Ethanol supplies must be adequate Ethanol logistics must be in place Refinery modifications must be completed Gasoline supply (imports) must be available Import infrastructure must be sufficient to accommodate anticipated increase in imports “Successful” means that transition to ethanol occurs without disruption to the market and minimal impact on consumers and the economy
Ethanol supplies must be adequate
Ethanol logistics must be in place
Refinery modifications must be completed
Gasoline supply (imports) must be available
Import infrastructure must be sufficient to
accommodate anticipated increase in imports
“Successful” means that transition to ethanol
occurs without disruption to the market and
minimal impact on consumers and the
economy

page.title:
Anticipated Impacts of MTBE Removal
Anticipated Impacts of MTBE Removal
page.enlisting:
Demand for ethanol will increase – Calif. will require significant quantities of ethanol • 560 to 580 million gallons by 2003 • 760 to 990 million gallons by 2004 – Current US ethanol production capacity approximately 3 billion gallons per year – Energy Commission survey (December 2002) of ethanol industry concludes that supply should be sufficient to meet California’s incremental ethanol demand Demand for ethanol will increase – Calif. will require significant quantities of ethanol
Demand for ethanol will increase
– Calif. will require significant quantities of ethanol
• 560 to 580 million gallons by 2003 • 760 to 990 million gallons by 2004
• 560 to 580 million gallons by 2003
• 760 to 990 million gallons by 2004
– Current US ethanol production capacity approximately 3 billion gallons per year
– Current US ethanol production capacity
approximately 3 billion gallons per year
– Energy Commission survey (December 2002) of ethanol industry concludes that supply should be sufficient to meet California’s incremental ethanol demand
– Energy Commission survey (December 2002) of
ethanol industry concludes that supply should be
sufficient to meet California’s incremental ethanol
demand

page.title:
Other Issues Affecting California
Other Issues Affecting California
page.footer:
• Sources from outside the US could command higher
• Sources from outside the US could command higher
page.enlisting:
National energy legislation - under debate – Renewable fuel standard (RFS) • Adoption of RFS could significantly increase demand for ethanol, potentially straining supplies, unless “planned” capacity expansions receive funding and complete construction per announced schedules • Elimination of Federal oxygen requirement could help, but California is still expected to require significant amounts of ethanol regardless of the minimum oxygen requirement – National MTBE phaseout • Mandatory elimination of MTBE in rest of country would • Demand for clean blending components to replace lost National energy legislation - under debate – Renewable fuel standard (RFS)

– Renewable fuel standard (RFS)
• Adoption of RFS could significantly increase demand for ethanol, potentially straining supplies, unless “planned” capacity expansions receive funding and complete construction per announced schedules

• Elimination of Federal oxygen requirement could help, but California is still expected to require significant amounts of ethanol regardless of the minimum oxygen requirement

page.title:
Other Issues (cont.)
Other Issues (cont.)
page.enlisting:
Cleaner fuel standards for gasoline and diesel fuel – Lower sulfur levels for gasoline and diesel fuel in the US may lead to further refinery consolidation • Additional need to import cleaner components Stricter fuel standards in other countries – Competition for clean components will increase unless refinery capacity expansions keep pace with growing demand Reduction of contributions to federal highway account – Use of ethanol reduces federal excise tax – California contributions will decline significantly Cleaner fuel standards for gasoline and diesel fuel – Lower sulfur levels for gasoline and diesel fuel in the US may lead to further refinery consolidation
Cleaner fuel standards for gasoline and
diesel fuel
– Lower sulfur levels for gasoline and diesel fuel in
the US may lead to further refinery consolidation
• Additional need to import cleaner components Stricter fuel standards in other countries – Competition for clean components will increase unless refinery capacity expansions keep pace with growing demand

page.enlisting:
March 14 - Governor Davis orders investigation of high prices – Assessment will include gasoline, diesel fuel, natural gas and electrical generators – Energy Commission and Public Utilities Commission will conduct analysis – Study to be completed within 15 days March 14 - Governor Davis orders investigation of high prices – Assessment will include gasoline, diesel fuel,

Closing Remarks
Closing Remarks
page.enlisting:
Transition away from MTBE will be completed later this year Energy Commission will continue to monitor the transition and adequacy of supplies Growing demand for gasoline and anticipated production declines will increase the need to import clean blending components Costs to produce gasoline may be greater on a sustained basis
